answer: This answer is from Austria.txt:  The text describes the following types of pollution:  1. Pesticides: The text discusses the reduction of plant protection products, which are essentially pesticides, and their impact on biodiversity.  2. Fertilizer: The text mentions nutrient losses from fertilizers and the need to reduce the use of mineral fertilizers while maintaining soil fertility.  3. Nitrogen: The text refers to the reduction of agricultural gaseous nitrogen emissions, including ammonia emissions, to reduce eutrophying nitrogen inputs.
sources: page 1 Government: Austria National target title: Plant protection products and fertilizers Description: The risk to biodiversity posed by the active substances of plant protection products put into circulation is significantly reduced, taking into account European requirements (50% reduction) as well as reductions already achieved in Austria.  The future Austrian contribution results from the definition of the Austrian target values in application of the new EU Regulation on the sustainable use of plant protection products and amending Regulation (EU) 2021/2115.  The use of plant protection products in active substance group 3 of the Harmonised Risk Indicator HRI-1 (“particularly hazardous substitution candidates”) has decreased significantly when comparing the periods 2015–2017 and 2028–2030, taking into account future European requirements (reduction by 50%, new EU Regulation on the sustainable use of plant protection products and amending Regulation (EU) 2021/2115).  Nutrient losses from fertilisers are significantly reduced, taking into account European requirements (50% reduction, EU Biodiversity Strategy 2030), while at the same time avoiding a deterioration in soil fertility and taking into consideration the upstream services already provided by Austria.  The need for mineral fertilisers while maintaining soil fertility is reduced by 20% in line with the NECP measure.  Main policy measures: Measures to be implemented immediately are: Further development and application of a more suitable ecotoxicological indicator for the risk assessment of plant protection products on biodiversity as part of the active substance assessment at EU level.  Implementation an impact assessment of the reduction of plant protection products (including competitiveness and security of supply) and the reduction of fertilisers.  Implementation of the National Action Plan on the sustainable use of plant protection products ( NAP ), in particular with regard to the reduction targets for plant protection products.  Promotion of research into alternative plant protection methods and active substances and their provision.  Strengthening of natural pest control through the targeted creation of biodiversity areas and landscape elements (see Chapter 1.3.1) and promoting research projects to assess their effectiveness.  Promotion of the use of drift-reducing techniques when applying any plant protection products in order to minimise the impact on non-target areas and organisms.  Promotion of the breeding of resistant varieties of locally adapted crops, including organic and seed-resistant varieties, and greater consideration for these traits in variety testing.  Promotion of crop rotation measures or specifications for crop diversification that help to further reduce the use of pesticides and fertilisers (as a contribution to integrated plant protection).  Implementation of the measures of the future Ammonia Reduction Regulation and the NECP to reduce agricultural gaseous nitrogen emissions, including ammonia emissions to reduce eutrophying nitrogen inputs.  Promotion of graduated meadow cultivation as part of rural development (implementation of measures and further training).  Increase in the proportion of solid manure and compost in the application of farm fertiliser on grassland.  Expansion of advisory and training services for farmers for the increased use of more specific active substances and the more targeted use of these active substances.  Advice on precision farming, crop diversity and crop rotation.  (Precision farming serves to ensure a more efficient use of resources and the least possible negative impact on the environment; developments in the field of smart farming provide strategies for selecting suitable varieties, plant protection products or fertilisers).  Evaluation of buffer strips in accordance with the Nitrate Action Programme and GLÖZ 4 (creation of buffer strips along watercourses with a focus on water bodies with material pollution) with regard to their impact on biodiversity.  Development and implementation of a reduction programme for pesticide applications in domestic and allotment gardens.  Discussion of a reduction programme for pesticide applications in protected areas.  Expansion of advisory services and educational programmes for non-professional users with regard to the use of plant protection products.  Continuation and further development of the “plant protection warning service”.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: nan

answer: This answer is from Canada.txt:  The text describes several types of pollution that Canada is addressing:  1. **Excess Nutrients**: Efforts are being made to reduce excess nutrients lost to the environment, particularly phosphorus, to protect freshwater ecosystems like the Great Lakes and Lake Winnipeg.  2. **Pesticides**: The text mentions reducing the overall risk from pesticides, including through integrated pest management and monitoring pesticide concentrations in water.  3. **Hazardous Chemicals**: The Chemicals Management Plan assesses and manages risks from a wide range of substances, including persistent organic pollutants and chemicals of emerging concern.  4. **Plastic Pollution**: Canada is working towards preventing, reducing, and eliminating plastic pollution, including efforts to advance a circular plastics economy and reduce plastics from industrial discharges and wastewater.  5. **Air Pollutants**: Measures are in place to reduce air pollution from industry, transportation, and consumer products, and to improve air quality through Canada's Air Quality Management System.  6. **Oil Pollution**: The Integrated Satellite Tracking of Pollution (ISTOP) Program detects and reports oil pollution in Canadian waters to minimize coastal water pollution.  These efforts are part of a broader strategy to reduce pollution risks and their negative impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem functions.
sources: page 1 Government: Canada National target title: Pollution and biodiversity Description: Reduce pollution risks and the negative impact of pollution from all sources, by 2030, to levels that are not harmful to biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services, considering cumulative effects, including: reducing excess nutrients lost to the environment by at least half including through more efficient nutrient cycling and use; reducing the overall risk from pesticides and highly hazardous chemicals by at least half including through integrated pest management, based on science, taking into account food security and livelihoods; and also preventing, reducing, and working towards eliminating plastic pollution.  Pollution is one of the five largest direct drivers of global biodiversity loss.  It impacts biodiversity by disrupting ecosystem functions and reducing the resilience of the systems and organisms living within them.  Pollution also has negative impacts on human health.  The triple crises of biodiversity loss, climate change, and pollution are intrinsically connected.  Minimizing biodiversity loss by addressing risk associated with pollution is crucial to sustainably maintaining ecosystem functions and services.  Main policy measures: Nutrients Led by ECCC, the 2023-2033 Freshwater Action Plan aims to achieve Canada's Lake Erie phosphorus load reduction targets by 2039 through the adoption of an innovative precision conservation approach whereby areas contributing the highest phosphorus loads will be identified, and suites of partner-led actions that will yield the greatest results will be advanced.  The Freshwater Action Plan also aims to complete the clean-up of 12 of 14 remaining Canadian Great Lakes Areas of Concern by 2030 and all 14 by 2038.  It also aims to establish Canada-US nutrient reduction targets for all Canadian Great Lakes.  Efforts will advance targeted strategies to accelerate reduction of nutrient pollution to other major lakes (e.g., Lake Winnipeg) and freshwater ecosystems.  Pesticides and nutrients Beneficial management practices (BMPs) and technologies optimize agricultural pesticide application to reduce losses and mitigate potential risks.  Under successive federal-provincial-territorial Agricultural Policy Frameworks, including the current Sustainable Canadian Agricultural Partnership (2023-2028), provinces and territories (PTs) design and deliver agri-environmental programs.  AAFC leads the delivery of other federal programs, such as the Agricultural Climate Solutions program.  These programs support increased on-farm adoption of BMPs and minimize impacts and enhance benefits to biodiversity, through support for the development and adoption of practices to improve soil health, avoid excess application of nutrients, and reduce the risk of nutrient runoff, among other things.  These programs also facilitate and support knowledge transfer on tools and approaches for nutrient and pest management, to increase awareness and usability of practices and technologies that reduce environmental risks.  AAFC also conducts and supports research and development to enhance BMPs and technologies in agriculture, including the co-development of scientifically proven and economically viable Integrated Pest Management and Nutrient Management practices with stakeholders, and accelerating the research, development, and adoption of alternative pest management solutions.  Pesticides HC leads the Rapid Priority Review Stream for Lower Risk Pesticides, which approves lower-risk pesticides through a streamlined process and tiered data requirements, compared to conventional pesticides.  HC is expanding a monitoring pilot project to a National-Scale Water Monitoring Program for Pesticides, which will collect real-world data from pesticide monitoring programs in Canada, particularly on pesticide concentrations that could cause acute and/or chronic impacts to invertebrates, fish, and plants in water.  This data will directly support decision making related to environmental impacts and risk assessments.  HC is also developing a Pesticide Use Information Framework, a multi-pronged model for access, delivery, and management of pesticide information.  Accurate characterization of risks associated with pesticides will support regulatory decisions and the development of risk management options, leading to increased protections for the environment and biodiversity to help reduce risk.  NRCan conducts scientific research activities supporting implementation of the Forest Pest Risk Management: National Research Agenda (2019-2029) to contribute to reducing the use of chemical forest pest control through ongoing development and evaluation of science-based alternative forest pest control tools and strategies.  Chemicals The Chemicals Management Plan, led by ECCC and HC, includes assessing and managing risks to the environment and health from a wide range of substances in consumer products, food, cosmetics, drugs, drinking water, pesticides, and industrial releases.  This includes ensuring that no new substances are introduced into the Canadian marketplace before undergoing ecological and health risk assessments, and the implementation of management measures when required.  CIRNAC will continue to lead the Northern Contaminants Program, in partnership with ECCC, DFO, HC, northern Indigenous organizations, and others, to facilitate the monitoring and assessment of persistent organic pollutants and chemicals of emerging Arctic concern, in support of northern public health advice, the work of the Stockholm Convention and of the Arctic Council.  ECCC will continue the Great Lakes Water Quality Monitoring and Surveillance Program for chemicals of mutual concern (US-Canada), contributing Canadian monitoring, data, and scientific expertise to the State of the Great Lakes report, in support of the Canada-US Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement.  page 1 Under the Whales Initiative, DFO and ECCC are examining the threat of contaminants on key priority whale species and their prey.  This work involves monitoring of contaminants in air, freshwater, wastewater, sediment, whales, and their prey.  The Integrated Satellite Tracking of Pollution (ISTOP) Program, operated by ECCC together with TC, uses RADARSAT Constellation Mission data to detect and report on oil pollution in Canadian waters.  This is part of an ongoing effort to minimize or eliminate coastal water pollution, which adversely affects marine birds, mammals, and their ecosystems.  Plastics ECCC, DFO, CIRNAC, NRC, TC, StatCan, NRCan, and HC are working to advance a circular plastics economy to prevent and reduce plastic pollution on several fronts (e.g., science, innovation, mobilizing Canadians, international actions).  ECCC is working with PTs to implement the Canada-wide Strategy and Action Plan on Zero Plastic Waste, which includes developing guidance to prevent and reduce plastics from entering the environment from industrial discharges and wastewater treatment systems.  CIRNAC, ECCC, DFO, and HC are advancing Canada's Plastic Science Agenda to gather information on plastic waste in the environment, track the effectiveness of actions, and inform policy development.  Two Innovation Solution Canada challenges have been funded in relation to marine shipping, on novel ways to reuse and recycle fiberglass from end-of-life vessels, and on prototype technology that can be fitted on a vessel to capture microplastics in greywater.  TC continues to engage on the International Maritime Organization's Action Plan to address marine plastic litter from ships.  Air pollutants ECCC establishes and administers regulatory and non-regulatory measures to reduce air pollution from industry, and consumer and commercial products.  ECCC and TC establish and administer measures to reduce air pollutant emissions from transportation.  ECCC also implements Canada's Air Quality Management System, which provides a cross-Canada framework to reduce air pollutant emissions and improve air quality in collaboration with PTs.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: The 2030 Strategy addresses the KMGBFâ€™s four goals to 2050 and 23 targets to 2030, matching the level of ambition of the KMGBF for each one.  The targets represent an integrated package where each is critical to the success of the whole.  Addressing targets in isolation will be inefficient and ineffective; rather, the 2030 Strategy strives to take a holistic approach that advances multiple priorities in parallel, maximizes co-benefits, and seeks to navigate any trade-offs.  Of note, Targets 21, 22, and 23 (knowledge sharing; inclusion of Indigenous Peoples, women, and youth in decision making; and gender equality, respectively) play a key role in laying the foundation that cuts across all targets to achieve an approach that reduces inequalities in biodiversity policy and decision making.  Canada is largely adopting each target as-is from the KMGBF, recognizing that the suite of targets represents a holistic package, with each one being critical to the overall goal of halting and reversing biodiversity loss.  In some cases (e.g., the collective resource mobilization goals of Target 19), targets do not have a direct Canadian equivalent, only a global number, which Canada will contribute to.  But in all cases, we are adopting the targets with the full ambition of the KMGBF.

Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Explicación que incluya qué aspectos del objetivo o la meta se abarcan.  ¿ Qué Aspectos del KMGBF se Abordan en la Meta Nacional 7?  Al analizar la Meta Nacional 7, podemos identificar cómo se vinculan los objetivos estratégicos, las metas y los medios de implementación del KMGBF con las acciones específicas de Guinea Ecuatorial: Objetivos Estratégicos: Poner fin a la pérdida de biodiversidad: La contaminación es una de las principales causas de pérdida de biodiversidad.  Al abordar la contaminación, Guinea Ecuatorial contribuye directamente a este objetivo.  Conservar y restaurar: La meta de restaurar ecosistemas degradados por la contaminación se alinea directamente con el objetivo de conservar y restaurar la biodiversidad.  Asegurar el uso sostenible de la biodiversidad: Al reducir la contaminación, se promueve un uso más sostenible de los recursos naturales, asegurando su disponibilidad para las generaciones futuras.  Metas Específicas: Medios de Implementación: Reducir el riesgo de extinción: Al disminuir la contaminación, se reducen las presiones sobre las especies amenazadas, contribuyendo a disminuir su riesgo de extinción.  Proteger y conservar áreas: Aunque no se menciona explícitamente, la reducción de la contaminación mejora la calidad de los hábitats, lo que indirectamente contribuye a la meta de proteger un porcentaje mayor de áreas terrestres y marinas.  Restaurar ecosistemas: La meta de restaurar ecosistemas degradados por la contaminación se alinea directamente con la meta global de restaurar al menos el 30% de los ecosistemas degradados.  Movilización de Recursos: Guinea Ecuatorial probablemente está buscando financiamiento internacional y nacional para implementar las acciones de la Meta Nacional 7.  Desarrollo de Capacidades: Se invierte en la capacitación del personal técnico y en el fortalecimiento de las instituciones gubernamentales responsables de la gestión ambiental.  Cooperación Internacional: Se establecen alianzas con otros países y organizaciones internacionales para compartir conocimientos y experiencias.  Participación de las Comunidades Locales: Se busca la participación de las comunidades locales en la toma de decisiones y en la implementación de las acciones de conservación.  ¿Cómo se Ha Hecho Esta Vinculación?  Incorporación en la Planificación Nacional: Los objetivos del KMGBF se han integrado en los planes de desarrollo nacional y sectoriales de Guinea Ecuatorial.  Creación de Instrumentos de Gestión: Se han desarrollado instrumentos como planes de gestión ambiental, sistemas de monitoreo y áreas protegidas.  Fortalecimiento de la Gobernanza Ambiental: Se ha creado un marco institucional más sólido para la gestión ambiental.  Movilización de Recursos Financieros: Se han buscado fuentes de financiamiento nacionales e internacionales.  Desarrollo de Capacidades: Se ha invertido en la capacitación del personal técnico y en la transferencia de tecnología.  Cooperación Internacional: Se han establecido alianzas con otros países y organizaciones internacionales.  En resumen, la Meta Nacional 7 de Guinea Ecuatorial demuestra un claro compromiso con los objetivos globales de conservación de la biodiversidad establecidos en el Marco de Kunming-Montreal.  Al abordar la contaminación, un factor clave en la pérdida de biodiversidad, Guinea Ecuatorial contribuye a la protección de sus ecosistemas y al bienestar de las futuras generaciones.  Government: Equatorial Guinea National target title: META NACIONAL 14: Para el año 2.030, Aumentar la conciencia pública en todas las capas de la sociedad sobre la importancia de la conservación de la biodiversidad y el uso sostenible de los recursos naturales.  Description: Análisis de la Meta Nacional 14 para el CBD en Guinea Ecuatorial La Meta Nacional 14 se centra en un aspecto fundamental para la conservación de la biodiversidad: la sensibilización pública .  El objetivo es lograr que la sociedad en su conjunto, desde los tomadores de decisiones hasta la población en general, comprenda la importancia de la biodiversidad y adopte prácticas más sostenibles.  Objetivos Específicos: Aumentar el conocimiento: Incrementar el nivel de conocimiento de la población sobre la biodiversidad, sus beneficios y las amenazas que la enfrentan.  Fomentar actitudes positivas: Promover actitudes positivas hacia la conservación de la biodiversidad y la adopción de prácticas sostenibles.  Empoderar a la ciudadanía: Empoderar a la ciudadanía para que participe activamente en la conservación de la biodiversidad.  Importancia de la Meta Base para la acción: Una población consciente y sensibilizada es más propensa a apoyar y participar en iniciativas de conservación.  Cambio de comportamientos: La sensibilización puede conducir a cambios en los comportamientos individuales y colectivos, favoreciendo prácticas más sostenibles.  Legitimación de las políticas: Una población informada y comprometida facilita la implementación de políticas de conservación y el cumplimiento de la legislación ambiental.  Main policy measures: Medidas de políticas o acciones que se adoptarán para alcanzar esta meta nacional Para alcanzar la Meta Nacional 14, que busca aumentar la conciencia pública sobre la importancia de la biodiversidad en Guinea Ecuatorial, es necesario implementar una serie de medidas políticas y acciones concretas.  page 1 Creación de mecanismos de coordinación: Establecer mecanismos de coordinación entre las diferentes instituciones involucradas en la implementación.  Monitoreo y evaluación: Implementar sistemas de monitoreo y evaluación para medir el progreso y los resultados de las acciones emprendidas.  Ejemplos Concretos: Talleres de co-creación: Organizar talleres con comunidades locales para co-crear soluciones basadas en la naturaleza y garantizar que sus conocimientos tradicionales sean integrados en las nuevas leyes.  Plataforma digital de participación: Crear una plataforma en línea donde los ciudadanos puedan enviar sus comentarios y sugerencias sobre los borradores de las leyes.  Programas de capacitación para jueces y fiscales: Capacitar a los operadores de justicia en la aplicación de las nuevas leyes ambientales.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Qué aspectos del objetivo o la meta se abarcan.  El Marco de Kunming-Montreal para la Biodiversidad (KMGBF) establece un nuevo estándar global para la conservación de la naturaleza.  Guinea Ecuatorial, al formular su Meta Nacional 15, ha demostrado un compromiso con la implementación de este marco al integrar varias de sus consideraciones clave.  A continuación, se detallan algunas de las formas en que se han aplicado estas consideraciones y qué aspectos específicos del objetivo o la meta se abarcan: Integración de las Consideraciones del KMGBF en la Meta Nacional 15 Enfoque ecosistémico: KMGBF: Promueve una gestión integral de los ecosistemas.  Meta Nacional 15: La revisión y actualización del marco legal ambiental aborda la gestión de ecosistemas terrestres y marinos, asegurando una protección más integral de la biodiversidad.  Justicia ambiental: KMGBF: Subraya la importancia de la equidad en la distribución de los beneficios y las cargas asociadas a la conservación y el uso sostenible de la biodiversidad.  Meta Nacional 15: La propuesta de realizar consultas públicas y fortalecer las organizaciones de la sociedad civil busca garantizar una participación más equitativa de las comunidades locales en la toma de decisiones.  Financiamiento sostenible: KMGBF: Recalca la necesidad de movilizar recursos financieros suficientes y predecibles a largo plazo.  Meta Nacional 15: La propuesta de crear un fondo nacional para la biodiversidad y explorar diversas fuentes de financiamiento asegura una base financiera sólida para la implementación de la meta a largo plazo.  Capacidades: KMGBF: Subraya la importancia de fortalecer las capacidades institucionales y humanas.  Meta Nacional 15: La propuesta de capacitar al personal de las instituciones gubernamentales y fortalecer las organizaciones de la sociedad civil garantiza que el país cuente con los recursos humanos necesarios para implementar las nuevas políticas ambientales.  Cooperación internacional: KMGBF: Promueve la cooperación internacional para compartir conocimientos y experiencias.  Meta Nacional 15: La propuesta de establecer alianzas estratégicas con organizaciones internacionales y otros países permite acceder a conocimientos y tecnologías externas, acelerando así el progreso hacia la conservación de la biodiversidad.  Monitoreo y evaluación: KMGBF: Enfatiza la importancia de establecer sistemas de monitoreo y evaluación para medir el progreso hacia los objetivos de biodiversidad.  Meta Nacional 15: La propuesta de realizar evaluaciones periódicas permite hacer un seguimiento del progreso y ajustar las estrategias según sea necesario, asegurando que se estén alcanzando los objetivos establecidos.  Aspectos Específicos Abordados Marco legal: La revisión y actualización del marco legal ambiental aborda aspectos como la protección de especies amenazadas, la gestión de áreas protegidas, y la regulación de actividades que pueden tener un impacto negativo en la biodiversidad.  Gestión de ecosistemas: Se busca una gestión más integrada de los ecosistemas terrestres y marinos, considerando las interconexiones entre ellos y los servicios ecosistémicos que proporcionan.  Participación ciudadana: Se promueve una mayor participación de la sociedad civil en la toma de decisiones relacionadas con la conservación de la biodiversidad.  Financiamiento: Se busca asegurar una fuente de financiamiento sostenible para la implementación de las acciones de conservación a largo plazo.  Capacidades institucionales: Se fortalecerán las capacidades de las instituciones gubernamentales para implementar las nuevas políticas ambientales.  Cooperación internacional: Se establecerán alianzas estratégicas para acceder a conocimientos, tecnologías y financiamiento externo.  En resumen, la Meta Nacional 15 de Guinea Ecuatorial busca abordar de manera integral los aspectos clave de la conservación de la biodiversidad, tal como se establece en el Marco de Kunming-Montreal.  Al fortalecer el marco legal, promover la participación ciudadana, asegurar el financiamiento necesario y desarrollar las capacidades institucionales, Guinea Ecuatorial está dando pasos significativos hacia la protección de su rica biodiversidad.  Government: Equatorial Guinea National target title: META 16: Para el 2.030, aumentar las alternativas, consideraciones de consumo, políticas sostenibles, enseñanza y el acceso a la información, incentivaciones y reconocimientos relativos a las personas físicas y jurídicas que utilizan y manejan de forma racional los recursos biológicos en todo el territorio nacional.  Description: La Meta Nacional 16 del Convenio sobre la Diversidad Biológica (CDB) para Guinea Ecuatorial representa un ambicioso objetivo de promover una relación más sostenible entre los habitantes del país y su entorno natural.  En esencia, busca fomentar una cultura de valoración, conservación y uso responsable de los recursos biológicos ¿Qué significa esto en términos prácticos?  page 1 A continuación, se proponen algunas: 1.  Educación Ambiental: Incorporación en el currículo escolar: Integrar la educación ambiental en todos los niveles educativos, desde la primaria hasta la universidad, con énfasis en la biodiversidad local.  Formación de docentes: Capacitar a los docentes para que puedan impartir clases sobre biodiversidad de manera efectiva y atractiva.  Programas extracurriculares: Organizar clubes de ecología, campamentos ambientales y concursos para fomentar el interés de los jóvenes por la naturaleza.  2.  Campañas de Sensibilización: Uso de medios de comunicación: Utilizar la radio, la televisión, los periódicos y las redes sociales para difundir mensajes clave sobre la importancia de la biodiversidad.  Eventos y festivales: Organizar eventos culturales y festivales temáticos para sensibilizar a la población sobre la biodiversidad.  Materiales educativos: Elaborar materiales educativos atractivos y accesibles para diferentes públicos, como guías de campo, videos, infografías y juegos.  3.  Participación Ciudadana: Foros y talleres: Organizar foros y talleres para que la ciudadanía participe en la toma de decisiones sobre la gestión de los recursos naturales.  Voluntariado ambiental: Promover el voluntariado ambiental para involucrar a la población en actividades de conservación.  Redes sociales: Utilizar las redes sociales para conectar a las personas interesadas en la conservación y facilitar el intercambio de información.  4.  Políticas Públicas: Legislación ambiental: Fortalecer la legislación ambiental y garantizar su cumplimiento.  Incentivos económicos: Ofrecer incentivos económicos para promover prácticas sostenibles, como la agricultura ecológica y el ecoturismo.  Áreas protegidas: Ampliar la red de áreas protegidas y mejorar su gestión.  5.  Cooperación Internacional: Acuerdos bilaterales: Establecer acuerdos de cooperación con otros países para compartir experiencias y conocimientos en materia de conservación.  Financiamiento internacional: Buscar financiamiento internacional para proyectos de conservación y educación ambiental.  Participación en foros internacionales: Participar activamente en foros internacionales sobre biodiversidad para dar a conocer las iniciativas de Guinea Ecuatorial.  6.  Investigación Científica: Inventarios de biodiversidad: Realizar inventarios de la biodiversidad para conocer mejor las especies y los ecosistemas presentes en el país.  Estudios de impacto ambiental: Exigir la realización de estudios de impacto ambiental para todos los proyectos que puedan afectar la biodiversidad.  Monitoreo de la biodiversidad: Implementar sistemas de monitoreo para evaluar el estado de conservación de los ecosistemas y las especies.  7.  Sector Privado: Responsabilidad social corporativa: Promover la responsabilidad social corporativa entre las empresas para que integren la conservación de la biodiversidad en sus actividades.  Ecoturismo: Fomentar el desarrollo de un ecoturismo sostenible que genere beneficios tanto para la conservación como para las comunidades locales.  La implementación de estas medidas requerirá de una coordinación efectiva entre los diferentes actores involucrados, incluyendo el gobierno, la sociedad civil, el sector privado y las comunidades locales.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Qué aspectos del objetivo o la meta se abarcan.  El Marco de Kunming-Montreal establece un marco de referencia global para la conservación de la biodiversidad.  Para entender cómo Guinea Ecuatorial ha integrado estos aspectos en su Meta Nacional 14, es crucial analizar las acciones específicas que se han implementado o están planificadas.  A continuación, se detallan cómo los diferentes aspectos del Marco de Kunming-Montreal se han reflejado en la implementación de la Meta Nacional 14: 1.  Enfoque en las Personas y Comunidades Locales Participación: Las comunidades locales, especialmente aquellas que dependen directamente de los recursos naturales, han sido involucradas en la planificación y ejecución de proyectos de conservación.  Conocimiento tradicional: Se ha reconocido y valorado el conocimiento tradicional de las comunidades locales sobre la biodiversidad y se ha buscado integrarlo en las estrategias de conservación.  Beneficios compartidos: Se han diseñado mecanismos para garantizar que los beneficios de la conservación se distribuyan de manera equitativa entre las comunidades locales.  Por ejemplo , en algunos proyectos de conservación de manglares, las comunidades locales reciben pagos por los servicios ecosistémicos que proporcionan estos ecosistemas, como la protección costera y la captura de carbono.  2.  Soluciones Basadas en la Naturaleza Restauración: Se han implementado proyectos de restauración de ecosistemas degradados, como manglares y bosques, para mejorar la biodiversidad y los servicios ecosistémicos.  Por ejemplo , en algunas regiones de Guinea Ecuatorial se han llevado a cabo proyectos de reforestación con especies nativas para restaurar áreas degradadas.  Corredores ecológicos: Se han establecido corredores ecológicos para conectar fragmentos de hábitat y facilitar el movimiento de la fauna.  Por ejemplo , se han creado corredores ecológicos entre áreas protegidas para permitir la migración de especies como los elefantes.  Manejo sostenible: Se han promovido prácticas de manejo sostenible de los recursos naturales, como la pesca y la agricultura, para reducir su impacto en la biodiversidad.  Por ejemplo , se han establecido cuotas de pesca y se han promovido prácticas agrícolas sostenibles como la agroecología.  3.  Financiamiento Sostenible Mecanismos innovadores: Se han explorado diferentes mecanismos de financiamiento, como la venta de créditos de carbono y los pagos por servicios ecosistémicos, para asegurar la sostenibilidad financiera de los proyectos de conservación.  page 1 En esencia, busca fomentar una cultura de valoración, conservación y uso responsable de los recursos biológicos ¿Qué significa esto en términos prácticos?  Esta meta plantea la necesidad de: Cambiar la forma en que consumimos: Promover un consumo más consciente, reduciendo el desperdicio y optando por productos que hayan sido producidos de manera sostenible.  Fomentar prácticas sostenibles: Impulsar la agricultura orgánica, la pesca responsable y el manejo forestal sostenible, entre otras.  Educar a la población: Informar y sensibilizar a la población sobre la importancia de la biodiversidad y cómo cada uno puede contribuir a su conservación.  Crear políticas ambientales efectivas: Desarrollar leyes y regulaciones que protejan los ecosistemas y los recursos naturales.  Reconocer y premiar buenas prácticas: Incentivar a las personas y organizaciones que contribuyen a la conservación de la biodiversidad.  ¿Por qué es importante esta meta?  Preservación de la biodiversidad: Guinea Ecuatorial posee una rica biodiversidad que es fundamental para el equilibrio de los ecosistemas y el bienestar humano.  Desarrollo sostenible: Un enfoque sostenible en la gestión de los recursos naturales es esencial para garantizar un futuro próspero para las generaciones venideras.  Mitigación del cambio climático: Los ecosistemas saludables desempeñan un papel crucial en la captura de carbono y la regulación del clima.  Seguridad alimentaria: La conservación de la biodiversidad agrícola es fundamental para garantizar la seguridad alimentaria a largo plazo.  Main policy measures: Medidas de políticas o acciones que se adoptarán para alcanzar esta meta nacional Para alcanzar la ambiciosa Meta Nacional 16 y garantizar la conservación de la biodiversidad y el desarrollo sostenible en Guinea Ecuatorial, es necesario implementar un conjunto de medidas políticas y acciones concretas.  A continuación, se presentan algunas propuestas: Marco Legal y Normativo Revisión y actualización de la legislación ambiental: Adaptar las leyes existentes y crear nuevas normativas para garantizar la protección de la biodiversidad y el uso sostenible de los recursos naturales.  Fortalecimiento de las instituciones ambientales: Dotar a las instituciones encargadas de la gestión ambiental de los recursos necesarios para cumplir con sus funciones.  Establecimiento de sistemas de evaluación de impacto ambiental: Implementar sistemas rigurosos para evaluar el impacto ambiental de proyectos y actividades.  Conservación de la Biodiversidad Ampliación del sistema de áreas protegidas: Crear nuevas áreas protegidas y fortalecer la gestión de las existentes, incluyendo la creación de corredores ecológicos.  Restauración de ecosistemas degradados: Implementar programas de restauración de bosques, manglares y otros ecosistemas degradados.  Combate a la deforestación: Adoptar medidas para reducir la tasa de deforestación, como la promoción de la agricultura sostenible y el control de la tala ilegal.  Gestión sostenible de los recursos pesqueros: Establecer cuotas de pesca, crear áreas marinas protegidas y promover la pesca artesanal sostenible.  Desarrollo Sostenible Promoción de la economía verde: Fomentar el desarrollo de sectores económicos sostenibles, como el ecoturismo, la agricultura orgánica y la energía renovable.  Diversificación económica: Reducir la dependencia de los ingresos provenientes de los recursos naturales y promover la diversificación económica.  Fomento de la investigación y el desarrollo: Invertir en investigación científica para desarrollar tecnologías y prácticas sostenibles adaptadas a las condiciones locales.  Participación Ciudadana y Educación Ambiental Sensibilización y educación ambiental: Implementar programas de educación ambiental dirigidos a todos los sectores de la población.  Participación ciudadana: Fomentar la participación de las comunidades locales en la toma de decisiones y la gestión de los recursos naturales.  Fortalecimiento de las organizaciones de la sociedad civil: Apoyar a las organizaciones de la sociedad civil que trabajan en la conservación de la biodiversidad.  Cooperación Internacional Establecer alianzas estratégicas: Colaborar con organizaciones internacionales, gobiernos de otros países y el sector privado para obtener financiamiento, tecnología y asistencia técnica.  Intercambio de experiencias: Participar en redes internacionales para compartir experiencias y buenas prácticas.  Financiamiento Diversificación de fuentes de financiamiento: Explorar diferentes fuentes de financiamiento, como fondos internacionales, donaciones y mecanismos de mercado.  Creación de mecanismos financieros innovadores: Desarrollar mecanismos financieros innovadores, como pagos por servicios ecosistémicos y bonos de carbono.  Monitoreo y Evaluación Establecimiento de indicadores: Definir indicadores claros y medibles para evaluar el progreso hacia la consecución de la meta.  Sistemas de monitoreo: Implementar sistemas de monitoreo para recopilar datos sobre el estado de la biodiversidad y la efectividad de las medidas implementadas.  Es importante destacar que la implementación exitosa de estas medidas requerirá un enfoque integral y coordinado, así como una fuerte voluntad política.  Además, será fundamental contar con el apoyo de todos los actores involucrados, incluyendo el gobierno, el sector privado, la sociedad civil y las comunidades locales.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Explicación que incluya qué aspectos del objetivo o la meta se abarcan.  ¿Qué Aspectos de la Meta Nacional 16 se Abordan Considerando el Marco de Kunming-Montreal?  page 1 Government: Equatorial Guinea National target title: META NACIONAL 7: Para 2030, establecer una línea de base de las diferentes fuentes y niveles de emisiones contaminantes actuales, así como los sistemas de mediciones para monitoreo de fuentes contaminantes y establecer medidas de mitigación.  Description: Descripción de la meta La Meta Nacional 7 de Guinea Ecuatorial, en el marco del Convenio sobre la Diversidad Biológica (CDB), busca establecer un sistema de monitoreo y control de la contaminación.  En esencia, el objetivo es comprender mejor la magnitud del problema de la contaminación y establecer las bases para reducirla.  En resumen, esta meta busca: Inventariar fuentes de contaminación: Identificar todas las fuentes que generan contaminantes en el país.  Cuantificar emisiones: Medir la cantidad de contaminantes que se liberan al ambiente.  Establecer un sistema de monitoreo: Crear un sistema para seguir de cerca los niveles de contaminación a lo largo del tiempo.  Implementar medidas de mitigación: Desarrollar estrategias para reducir las emisiones contaminantes.  Desglose y Implicaciones Esta meta reconoce que la contaminación es una de las principales amenazas para la biodiversidad.  Al establecer una línea de base y un sistema de monitoreo, Guinea Ecuatorial podrá tomar decisiones informadas sobre cómo reducir los impactos negativos de la contaminación en sus ecosistemas.  ¿Por qué es importante esta meta?  Conservación de la biodiversidad: La contaminación puede causar la pérdida de hábitats, la degradación de los ecosistemas y la extinción de especies.  Salud humana: La contaminación del aire, el agua y el suelo puede tener graves consecuencias para la salud humana.  Cumplimiento de acuerdos internacionales: Esta meta contribuye al cumplimiento de los compromisos internacionales de Guinea Ecuatorial en materia de protección del medio ambiente.  Desafíos y Oportunidades Desafíos: Falta de recursos: Implementar un sistema de monitoreo y control de la contaminación requiere de una inversión significativa en términos de recursos financieros y técnicos.  Capacidad institucional: Se requiere fortalecer las capacidades institucionales para diseñar y operar el sistema de monitoreo.  Complejidad de las fuentes de contaminación: Identificar y cuantificar todas las fuentes de contaminación puede ser un desafío.  Oportunidades: Mejora de la gestión ambiental: Un sistema de monitoreo eficaz puede mejorar la gestión ambiental del país.  Cooperación internacional: La cooperación con otros países y organizaciones internacionales puede facilitar el acceso a conocimientos y tecnologías.  Desarrollo de nuevas industrias: El control de la contaminación puede impulsar el desarrollo de industrias más limpias y sostenibles.  Main policy measures: Medidas de políticas o acciones que se adoptarán para alcanzar esta meta nacional La Meta Nacional 7, enfocada en la evaluación y mitigación de la contaminación, requiere de un conjunto de medidas políticas y acciones concretas para su implementación efectiva.  A continuación, se presentan algunas propuestas: 1.  Fortalecimiento del Marco Institucional y Legal Creación de un organismo rector: Establecer un organismo gubernamental encargado de coordinar y supervisar las acciones relacionadas con la calidad ambiental y la gestión de la contaminación.  Revisión y actualización de la legislación ambiental: Adaptar la legislación existente para incluir normas más estrictas sobre emisiones, descargas y gestión de residuos.  Desarrollo de planes de gestión ambiental: Elaborar planes de gestión ambiental a nivel nacional, sectorial y local.  2.  Inventario y Monitoreo de Fuentes Contaminantes Inventario detallado: Realizar un inventario exhaustivo de todas las fuentes de contaminación, incluyendo industrias, transporte, agricultura y actividades domésticas.  Sistema de monitoreo: Implementar una red de estaciones de monitoreo de la calidad del aire, agua y suelo, utilizando tecnologías modernas como sensores remotos y drones.  Bases de datos: Crear bases de datos centralizadas para almacenar y analizar los datos obtenidos del monitoreo.  3.  Desarrollo de Medidas de Mitigación Normas y regulaciones: Establecer normas más estrictas para las emisiones de contaminantes en diversos sectores (industria, transporte, etc.).  Incentivos económicos: Implementar mecanismos económicos como impuestos ambientales y programas de incentivos para promover prácticas más limpias.  Tecnologías limpias: Fomentar la adopción de tecnologías limpias en los sectores industrial, transporte y doméstico.  Gestión de residuos: Mejorar la gestión de residuos sólidos y líquidos, incluyendo la reducción, reutilización y reciclaje.  Restauración de ecosistemas: Implementar proyectos de restauración de ecosistemas degradados por la contaminación.  4.  Fortalecimiento de las Capacidades Capacitación técnica: Capacitar al personal técnico en el monitoreo, evaluación y gestión de la contaminación.  Cooperación internacional: Establecer alianzas con otros países y organizaciones internacionales para obtener asistencia técnica y financiera.  5.  Sensibilización y Participación Ciudadana Campañas de información: Desarrollar campañas de información para concienciar a la población sobre los problemas de la contaminación y la importancia de adoptar prácticas sostenibles.  Participación ciudadana: Fomentar la participación ciudadana en la toma de decisiones y en el monitoreo de la calidad ambiental.  6.  Financiamiento Sostenible Presupuesto nacional: Asignar un presupuesto adecuado para la implementación de las medidas de control y mitigación de la contaminación.  Mecanismos financieros innovadores: Explorar mecanismos financieros innovadores, como bonos verdes y fondos ambientales.  Cooperación internacional: Buscar financiamiento internacional a través de donaciones, préstamos y mecanismos de cooperación.  7.

answer: This answer is from Eswatini.txt:  The text describes the following types of pollution in Eswatini:  1. **Pesticides**: The country aims to reduce pesticide use, particularly focusing on phasing out highly hazardous pesticides, which contribute to water pollution, soil degradation, and harm to non-target species like pollinators.  2. **Plastic Pollution**: Eswatini targets the elimination of single-use plastics and a reduction in plastic waste, which threatens biodiversity, public health, and ecosystems.  3. **Excess Nutrients (Nitrogen and Phosphorus)**: The country seeks to reduce nutrient losses from agricultural sources, as nutrient runoff leads to water pollution, soil degradation, and biodiversity loss, particularly through eutrophication in water bodies.
sources: page 1 Government: Eswatini National target title: Target 7.1 By 2030, reduce pesticide use by 60% compared to baseline levels, focusing on phasing out highly hazardous pesticides and promoting integrated pest management (IPM) practices in agricultural production.  Description: nan Main policy measures: nan Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Target 7.1 aims to reduce pesticide use by 60% by 2030, focusing on phasing out highly hazardous pesticides and promoting Integrated Pest Management (IPM) practices in Eswatiniâ€™s agricultural sector.  This target is crucial given the countryâ€™s current reliance on pesticides, particularly in cash crop production, which contributes to water pollution, soil degradation, and harm to non-target species like pollinators.  The contamination of rivers and wetlands, vital for biodiversity and human consumption, highlights the urgency of this issue.  Reducing pesticide use through IPM and sustainable practices will mitigate these environmental risks, protect biodiversity, and enhance long-term agricultural productivity.  Furthermore, addressing pesticide-related health risks for farmers and rural communities is essential for promoting safer, more sustainable agricultural practices.  This target aligns with broader conservation goals and supports ecosystem resilience in Eswatini.  Elements of the global target covered are: Reduce pollution risks and negative impact of pollution From all sources Levels that are not harmful to biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services Considering cumulative effects Risks from pesticides and highly hazardous chemicals Integrated pest management Taking into account food security and livelihoods Government: Eswatini National target title: Target 7.3 By 2030, eliminate single-use plastics and reduce plastic waste by 60% compared to baseline levels through policy interventions, consumer education, and infrastructure development for waste management and recycling.  Description: nan Main policy measures: nan Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Target 7.3 aims to eliminate single-use plastics and reduce plastic waste by 60% by 2030 through policy interventions, consumer education, and the development of waste management and recycling infrastructure.  This target is highly relevant for Eswatini, where the government has already taken decisive steps, including the planned ban on single-use plastic bags effective December 1, 2024.  The ban, part of the broader Control of Plastic Bags Regulations of 2021, reflects the countryâ€™s commitment to addressing plastic pollution, which threatens biodiversity, public health, and ecosystemsâ€‹.Â Despite efforts like the Phatsa Sakho Nawe campaign, which promoted reusable bags, plastic waste remains a significant problem.  Achieving this target will require not only strong policy measures but also consumer education to shift behaviours and reduce plastic consumption.  In addition, investing in waste management and recycling infrastructure is critical for reducing plastic pollution and supporting a circular economy.  By combining regulatory action with community engagement and infrastructure development, Eswatini can significantly reduce its plastic footprint, contributing to both environmental sustainability and public health.  Elements of the target covered are: Reduce pollution risks and negative impact of pollution From all sources Levels that are not harmful to biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services Considering cumulative effects Taking into account food security and livelihoods Preventing, reducing, and working towards eliminating plastic pollution Government: Eswatini National target title: Target 7.2 By 2030, reduce nutrient losses (e.g., nitrogen and phosphorus) from agricultural sources by 60% compared to baseline levels through improved nutrient management practices, including precision agriculture, cover cropping, and wetland restoration.  Description: nan Main policy measures: nan Aspects of the goal or target are covered: Target 7.2 seeks to reduce nutrient losses, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus, from agricultural sources by 60% by 2030, through improved nutrient management practices like precision agriculture, cover cropping, and wetland restoration.  This target is crucial for Eswatini as nutrient runoff from agriculture leads to water pollution, soil degradation, and the loss of biodiversity, particularly through the process of eutrophication in water bodies.  Excess nitrogen and phosphorus runoff causes algal blooms, oxygen depletion, and the death of aquatic species, severely impacting ecosystems, and water quality.  Additionally, nitrate contamination in drinking water poses serious health risks, while nitrogen volatilization contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, exacerbating climate change.  By adopting sustainable practices that reduce nutrient losses, Eswatini can protect its waterways, enhance soil health, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve agricultural efficiency.  This approach aligns with the countryâ€™s broader environmental and food security goals, promoting a healthier, more sustainable agricultural system.  Elements of the global target covered are: Reduce pollution risks and negative impact of pollution From all sources Levels that are not harmful to biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services Considering cumulative effects Reducing excess nutrients lost to the environment Taking into account food security and livelihoods

answer: This answer is from European Union.txt:  The text describes several types of pollution, including:  1. **Plastic Pollution**: This includes plastic litter at sea and microplastics released into the environment. The EU aims to reduce plastic litter at sea by 50% and microplastics by 30% by 2030.  2. **Air Pollution**: The Zero Pollution Action Plan targets reducing air pollution to levels no longer harmful to health and ecosystems by 2050.  3. **Water Pollution**: This includes pollution from hazardous chemicals and microplastics, with measures to protect drinking water and reduce pollutants in freshwaters.  4. **Soil Pollution**: The EU aims to reduce soil contamination and improve soil health by 2050.  5. **Nutrient Pollution**: The EU plans to reduce nutrient losses from agriculture by 50% by 2030.  6. **Pesticide Pollution**: The goal is to reduce the overall use and risk of chemical pesticides by 50% by 2030.  7. **Hazardous Chemicals**: The EU aims to phase out harmful chemicals, including endocrine disruptors and persistent substances.  8. **Mercury Pollution**: There are measures to phase out mercury use and manage mercury waste.  9. **Industrial Emissions**: Efforts are in place to control pollution from industrial activities.  These pollution types are addressed through various legislative and policy measures outlined in the context.
sources: page 1 Government: European Union National target title: Reducing plastic pollution Description: By 2030, reduce by 50% plastic litter at sea and by 30% microplastics released into the environment.  Main policy measures: Overview (target 7): The Zero Pollution Action Plan contains the overall target of reducing by 2050 air, water and soil pollution to levels no longer considered harmful to health and natural ecosystems and that respect the boundaries our planet can cope with, thus creating a toxic-free environment.  It further includes the specific target of reducing by 50% plastic litter at sea and by 30% microplastics released into the environment.  The Plastics Strategy aims to transform the way plastic products are designed, produced, used and recycled in the EU to protect our environment and reduce marine litter, greenhouse gas emissions and our dependence on imported fossil fuels.  Main legislation in place: The Directive on single-use plastics aims to prevent and reduce the impact of certain plastic products on the environment.  The Directive onÂ packaging , including the daughter Directive on plastics bags , which aim to prevent the production of packaging waste (in particular of plastic bags).  The Directive on Port Reception Facilities aims to protect the marine environment against the negative effects from discharges of waste from ships using ports located in the Union, while ensuring the smooth operation of maritime traffic.  The Waste Framework Directive and further waste management legislation, including the Delegated Regulation on plastic waste shipments .  The Marine Strategy Framework Directive (including Commission Decision (EU) 2017/848 ) establishes a framework within which Member States shall take the necessary measures to achieve or maintain good environmental status in the marine environment.  In order to do so, they must monitor quantities and impacts of marine litter, including plastic, set environmental targets, and take the necessary measures so as to ensure that quantities and impacts of litter do not harm the environment or biodiversity.  The Recast Drinking Water Directive aims to protect human health from the adverse effects of any contamination of water intended for human consumption and includes provisions to address emerging compounds of concern such as microplastics (i.e.  Article 13(6)).  The Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive concerns the collection, treatment and discharge of urban waste water and the treatment and discharge of waste water from certain industrial sectors.  The Commission Regulation concerning the REACH restriction of synthetic polymer microparticles aims to restrict intentionally added microplastics.  The provisional agreement on the Revision of EU legislation on Packaging and Packaging Waste aims to establish requirements for the entire life cycle of packaging as regards environmental sustainability and labelling.  In particular, Article 7 setting a minimum percentage of recycled content per packaging, Article 20 on plastic carrier bags and Article 46 setting recycling targets are of relevance.  The provisional agreement on the revision of the Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive contains new provisions on monitoring the presence of microplastics.  Legislation proposed: The Commission proposal on preventing pellet losses to reduce microplastic pollution aims to lay down obligations for the handling of plastic pellets at all stages of the supply chain to prevent losses.  The Commission proposal on water pollutants contains amendments to allow including microplasticsÂ in the next Watch List and add microplastics to the indicative list of main pollutants.  Other policy instruments: The Circular economy action plan includes specific commitments to propose mandatory requirements for recycled content and waste reduction measures for key products and to address the presence of microplastics in the environment.  The Plastics Strategy aims to transform the way plastic products are designed, produced, used and recycled in the EU to protect our environment and reduce marine litter, greenhouse gas emissions and our dependence on imported fossil fuels.  The Zero Pollution Action Plan includes the specific targets of reducing by 50% plastic litter at sea and by 30% microplastics released into the environment by 2030.  The first Zero Pollution Monitoring and Outlook offers a snapshot of the current state of the pollution in the EU and shows the progress made thus far on the 2030 zero pollution targets.  Monitoring of microplastic present in drinking water ( Recast Drinking Water Directive ), ground- & fresh water (Commission proposal on water pollutants ), wastewater ( Commission proposal for the revision of the Urban Wastewater treatment Directive ) and in coastal and marine waters under the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (see above).  The Transition Pathway for the Textiles ecosystem , co-created with stakeholders, identifies 50 specific actions to make the textiles ecosystem greener, more digital and to ensure its long-term resilience and competitiveness.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: This EU contribution aligns with GBF Target 7, the element concerning plastic pollution.  Together with other EU contributions, this EU contribution contributes to the EU implementation of Targets 4 and 10 Government: European Union National target title: Reducing pollution Description: Reduce by 2050 air, water and soil pollution to levels no longer considered harmful to health and natural ecosystems and that respect the boundaries our planet can cope with, thus creating a toxic-free environment, including through reducing by 50% the sale of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture, phase out mercury, reduce emissions of air pollutants and set environmental quality standards for priority hazardous substances in water.  page 1 Main policy measures: Overview (target 7): The Zero Pollution Action Plan contains the overall target of reducing by 2050 air, water and soil pollution to levels no longer considered harmful to health and natural ecosystems and that respect the boundaries our planet can cope with, thus creating a toxic-free environment.  The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability proposes measures to further phase out the most harmful chemicals, like endocrine disruptors and persistent substances.  Main legislation in place (non-exhaustive): The EU has a comprehensive chemicals framework comprising of more than 40 legislative instruments, of which the most important are listed below: The Regulation concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restrictions of Chemicals (REACH) is the main EU law to protect human health and the environment from the risks that can be posed by chemicals and gave way to a large number of secondary legislation.  The Biocidal Products Regulation concerns the making available on the market and use of biocidal products.  The Recast Regulation on persistent organic pollutants (POPs) lays down rules on persistent organic pollutants.  The Industrial Emissions Directive lays down rules on integrated prevention and control of pollution arising from industrial activities, as well as rules to prevent or reduce emissions into air, water and land and to prevent the generation of waste.  The Mercury Regulation establishes measures and conditions concerning the use and storage of and trade in mercury, mercury compounds and mixtures of mercury, and the manufacture and use of and trade in mercury-added products, and the management of mercury waste.  The Water Framework Directive establishes a framework for the protection of inland surface waters, transitional waters, coastal waters and groundwaters.  It sets, inter alia, environmental Quality Standards for priority and priority hazardous substances in water.  The Marine Strategy Framework Directive (including Commission Decision (EU) 2017/848 ) establishes a framework within which Member States shall take the necessary measures to achieve or maintain good environmental status in the marine environment.  The Recast Drinking Water Directive aims to protect human health from the adverse effects of any contamination of water intended for human consumption and includes provisions on e.g.  monitoring pollutants and establishing the minimum requirements on materials that come into contact with drinking water (Article 11).  The Seveso III Directive lays down rules for the prevention of major accidents which involve dangerous substances, and the limitation of their consequences for human health and the environment.  The National Emissions Reduction Commitments Directive establishes the emission reduction commitments for the Member States' anthropogenic atmospheric emissions of SO2, NOx, NMVOC, NH3 and PM2,5.  Article 9 on monitoring air pollution impacts on ecosystems is of particular relevance.  The European Industrial Emission Portal Regulation sets out rules on the reporting of environmental data from industrial installations.  The Regulation on Ecodesign for Sustainable Products aims to establish a framework for setting ecodesign requirements for sustainable products.  The provisional agreement on the Revision of the Industrial Emissions Directive aims to improve the Directiveâ€™s effectiveness in preventing or minimising the emissions of pollutants by agro-industrial installations at source and supports the transition towards the use of safer or less toxic chemicals, amongst others The provisional agreement on the revision of the Mercury Regulation sets out rules as regards dental amalgam and other mercury-added products subject to manufacturing, import and export restrictions.  The provisional agreement on the revision of the Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive includes a requirement for the removal of a broad spectrum of micro-pollutants (substances or their breakdown products considered hazardous to human health or the environment, as set out in Part 3 and Part 4 of Annex I to the REACH Regulation) from urban wastewaters by means of quaternary treatment.  The provisional agreement on the revision of the Regulation on classification, labelling and packaging of chemicals aims to clarify the rules on labelling chemical substances and the required information for chemicals sold online .  Legislation proposedÂ (non-exhaustive): The Commission proposal on water pollutants aims to improve the environmental quality of European freshwaters and protect the environment from the adverse effects of hazardous chemicals and air pollution.  The Commission proposal for a Regulation establishing a common data platform on chemicals , the Commission proposal for a Regulation on the re-attribution of scientific and technical tasks and improving cooperation among Union agencies and the Commission proposal for a Directive on the re-attribution of scientific and technical tasks to the European Chemicals Agency as part of the one-substance one-assessment package aim to streamline assessments of chemicals across EU legislation; strengthen the knowledge base on chemicals; and ensure early detection and action on emerging chemical risks.  Other policy instrumentsÂ (non-exhaustive): The Zero Pollution Action Plan (see implementation of actions ) includes specific targets such as reducing by 50% the use of more hazardous pesticides and the sale of antimicrobials for farm animals and in aquaculture by 2030.  The first Zero Pollution Monitoring and Outlook offers a snapshot of the current state of the pollution in the EU and shows the progress made thus far on the 2030 zero pollution targets.  The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability (see implementation of actions ) aims to better protect citizens and the environment from harmful chemicals, and boost innovation by promoting the use of safer and more sustainable chemicals.  page 1 In 2022, the Commission proposed certain amendments to the Directive .  The Marine Strategy Framework Directive (including Commission Decision (EU) 2017/848 ) establishes a framework within which Member States shall take the necessary measures to achieve or maintain good environmental status in the marine environment.  The Nitrates Directive lays down rules to reduce water pollution caused or induced by nitrates from agricultural sources and preventing further such pollution.  The Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive concerns the collection, treatment and discharge of urban waste water and the treatment and discharge of waste water from certain industrial sectors.  The Industrial Emissions Directive lays down rules on integrated prevention and control of pollution arising from industrial activities.  The provisional agreement on the revision of the Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive further reduces nutrient releases with more stringent limit values to treat nitrogen and phosphorus.  The provisional agreement on the Revision of the Industrial Emissions Directive improves the Directiveâ€™s effectiveness in preventing or minimising the emissions of pollutants by agro-industrial installations at source.  The National Emissions Reduction Commitments Directive establishes the emission reduction commitments for the Member States' anthropogenic atmospheric emissions of SO2, NOx, NMVOC, NH3 and PM2,5.  Article 9 on monitoring air pollution impacts on ecosystems is of particular relevance.  The Recast Drinking Water Directive aims to protect human health from adverse effects of any contamination of drinking water, and Article 4(2) requires Member States to ensure that their measures do not lead to the increase in pollution of waters used for the production of drinking water.  The European Industrial Emission Portal Regulation sets out rules on the reporting of environmental data from industrial installations.  Legislation proposed: The Commission proposal for a Soil Monitoring Law aims to put in place a soil monitoring framework and to continuously improve soil health in the Union to achieve healthy soils by 2050.  It requires Member States to address excess nutrient content in soil.  Other policy instruments: Zero Pollution Action Plan (see overview) The first Zero Pollution Monitoring and Outlook offers a snapshot of the current state of the pollution in the EU and shows the progress made thus far on the 2030 zero pollution targets.  The Farm to Fork Strategy includes the commitment to reduce nutrient losses by at least 50% while ensuring that there is no deterioration in soil fertility.  The Circular Economy Action Plan contains the commitment to develop an Integrated Nutrient Management Plan to ensure more sustainable application of nutrients and stimulating the markets for recovered nutrients.  EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2030 , in particular the following target and actions in the EU Biodiversity Strategy Actions Tracker : Target 13 â€“ The losses of nutrients from fertilisers are reduced by 50%, resulting in the reduction of the use of fertilisers by at least 20%.  Action 47: Take actions to reduce nutrient losses and pollution from nitrogen and phosphorus Action 48: Integrated Nutrient Management Action Plan Action 49: Zero Pollution Action Plan for Air, Water, and Soil Action 50: EU Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability The Commission Communication on ensuring availability and affordability of fertilisers aims to maintain a sustainable European fertilisersâ€™ production, optimise use and reduce dependency on mineral fertilisers .  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: This EU contribution aligns with GBF Target 7, the element concerning nutrients.  Together with other EU contributions, this EU contribution contributes to the EU implementation of Targets 4 and 10.  page 1 The Commission Recommendation for safe and sustainable chemicals aims to promote research and innovation for safer and more sustainable chemicals and materials.  EU Biodiversity Strategy , in particular the following actions in the EU Biodiversity Strategy Actions Tracker : Target 10: Significant progress in the remediation of contaminated soil sites.  Action 49: Zero Pollution Action Plan for Air, Water and Soil Action 50: EU Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability The Pharmaceuticals Strategy includes actions for high quality, safe and environmentally sustainable medicines.  The Transition Pathway for the Textiles ecosystem , co-created with stakeholders, identifies 50 specific actions to make the textiles ecosystem greener, more digital and to ensure its long-term resilience and competitiveness.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: This EU contribution aligns with GBF Target 7, the element on reducing pollution from all sources.  Together with other EU contributions, this EU contribution contributes to the EU implementation of Targets 4 and 10.  Government: European Union National target title: Reducing pesticides use and risk Description: By 2030, reduce the overall use and risk of chemical pesticides by 50% and the use of more hazardous pesticides by 50%.  Main policy measures: Overview (target 7): The Zero Pollution Action Plan contains the overall target of reducing by 2050 air, water and soil pollution to levels no longer considered harmful to health and natural ecosystems and that respect the boundaries our planet can cope with, thus creating a toxic-free environment.  It further includes the specific target of reducing the overall use and risk of chemical pesticides by 50% and the use of more hazardous pesticides by 50% by 2030.  Main legislation in place: The Regulation concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market and related legislation lay down rules for the authorisation of such products to ensure a high level of protection of human and animal health and the environment.  The Sustainable Use of Pesticides Directive establishes a framework to achieve a sustainable use of pesticides by reducing the risks and impacts of pesticide use on human health and the environment and promoting the use of integrated pest management and of alternative approaches or techniques such as non-chemical alternatives to pesticides.  The Water Framework Directive establishes a framework for the protection of inland surface waters, transitional waters, coastal waters and groundwaters, amongst others to reduce the pollution of groundwater and prevent further pollution.  The Recast Drinking Water Directive aims to protect human health from adverse effects of any contamination of drinking water, and Article 4(2) requires Member States to ensure that their measures do not lead to the increase in pollution of waters used for the production of drinking water.  The Marine Strategy Framework Directive (including Commission Decision (EU) 2017/848 ) establishes a framework within which Member States shall take the necessary measures to achieve or maintain good environmental status in the marine environment.  The Strategic Plans Regulation under the Common Agriculture Policy , notably Article 31(4)(f), requires Member States to establish eco-schemes, which can include actions for sustainable and reduced use of pesticides.  Legislation proposed: The Commission proposal for a Soil Monitoring Law aims to put in place a soil monitoring framework and to improve soil health to achieve healthy soils by 2050, amongst others to reduce soil contamination to levels no longer considered harmful to human health and the environment .  Other policy instruments: The Farm to Fork Strategy , the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2030 and the Zero Pollution Action Plan all include the commitment to reduce the overall use and risk of chemical pesticides by 50% and the use of more hazardous pesticides by 50% by 2030.  The Circular Economy Action Plan sets out actions for the EUâ€™s transition to a circular economy, which will reduce pressure on natural resources.  The first Zero Pollution Monitoring and Outlook offers a snapshot of the current state of the pollution in the EU and shows the progress made thus far on the 2030 zero pollution targets.  The Revision of the EU Pollinators Initiative - A new deal for pollinators aims, amongst other objectives, to mitigate the impacts of pesticide use on pollinators.  The Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability aims, amongst other actions, to develop an indicator framework on chemicals including pesticides by 2024.  Aspects of the goal or target are covered: This EU contribution aligns with GBF Target 7, the element on pesticides.  Together with other EU contributions, this EU contribution contributes to the EU implementation of Targets 4 and 10.  Government: European Union National target title: Reducing nutrient losses Description: By 2030, reduce by 50% nutrient losses from agriculture while ensuring that there is no deterioration in soil fertility and reduce by 25% the EU ecosystems where air pollution threatens biodiversity.  Main policy measures: Overview (target 7): The Zero Pollution Action Plan contains the overall target of reducing by 2050 air, water and soil pollution to levels no longer considered harmful to health and natural ecosystems and that respect the boundaries our planet can cope with, thus creating a toxic-free environment.  It further includes the specific targets of reducing nutrient losses from agriculture by 50% by 2030 and reducing by 25% the EU ecosystems where air pollution threatens biodiversity.  Main legislation in place: The Water Framework Directive establishes a framework for the protection of inland surface waters, transitional waters, coastal waters and groundwaters, amongst others to reduce the pollution of groundwater.  In 2022, the Commission proposed certain amendments to the Directive .

sources: page 1 Government: Fiji National target title: National Target 7: To reduce pollution point sources to levels that are not harmful to biodiversity Human Health, and Environment Description: Reduce Pollution to Levels That Are Not Harmful to Biodiversity Reduce pollution risks and the negative impact of pollution from all sources by 2030, to levels that are not harmful to biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services, considering cumulative effects, including: (a) by reducing excess nutrients lost to the environment by at least half, including through more efficient nutrient cycling and use; (b) by reducing the overall risk from pesticides and highly hazardous chemicals by at least half, including through integrated pest management, based on science, taking into account food security and livelihoods; and (c) by preventing, reducing, and working towards eliminating plastic pollution.  Main policy measures: nan Aspects of the goal or target are covered: nan
